properties.Name: ShipmentInsuranceExclusionType
properties.Description:
A term used to denote certain types of losses or causes of loss which are not covered by an insurance policy. 

Exclusions may be expressed in a policy or implied by law or custom. In general, there
are two types of exclusions:

Absolute Exclusions   
state that certain types of losses or causes of loss are excluded without
qualification (Example: excluding shortage, leakage or contamination)
 
Conditional Exclusions 
state that certain types of losses or causes of loss are excluded unless
certain events take place (Example: excluding shortage, leakage or contamination unless caused by stranding or collision).

Ex:
- Defects in transportation vehicle/vessel
- Criminal acts of transportation crew
- Acts of God
- Acts of War
- Misconduct of the assured
- Ordinary leakage or loss in weight
- Inherent vice
- Insufficiency or unsuitability of packing or preparation
- Delay
- Nuclear weapons of war
- Wars
- Strikes, riots and civil commotions
- Insolvency of ship owners
- Unseaworthiness or unfitness of vessel, container or conveyance
- Radioactive contamination  
- Barratry 
- Derelict mines torpedoes bombs or other derelict weapons of war.
- War civil war revolution rebellion insurrection
- Strikes, lockouts, labor disturbances, riots or civil commotions
- Ordinary leakage
- Loss, damage or expense due to delay
- Loss, damage or expense due to 
- Discharge of cargo at port of distress
- Earthquake, volcanic eruption or lightning
- Vessel stranded, grounded, sunk or capsized
- Discharge of cargo at port of distress
- Loss damage or expense attributable to willful misconduct of the Assured

Columns.Name: InsuranceExclusionTypeId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of an insurance exclusion type.

Columns.Name: InsuranceExclusionTypeName
Columns.Description: The name of an insurance exclusion type.

Columns.Name: InsuranceExclusionTypeDescription
Columns.Description: The description of an insurance exclusion type.
